title: 108_s1665
content: The Act may be cited as the "Private Security Officer Employment Authorization Act of 2003". Congress acknowledges the rapid growth of private security officers in the United States, recognizing their role in complementing public law enforcement to prevent and reduce crime. These officers protect individuals, property, and information across various sectors such as banking, healthcare, technology, energy, transportation, education, and residential areas. Private security officers in the United States play a significant role in complementing public law enforcement to combat crime and protect people, facilities, and institutions. The growth in security services has increased the availability of public sector law enforcement officers to address serious crimes, including terrorism. The American public deserves well-trained private security personnel to work alongside sworn law enforcement officers. Private security officers and applicants should undergo thorough screening and training to work effectively alongside sworn law enforcement officers. Private security officers and applicants should undergo thorough screening and training to work effectively alongside sworn law enforcement officers. The definitions are outlined in Section 3. In this Act, the term "employee" includes current employees and applicants for private security officer positions. An "authorized employer" is a person who employs private security officers and is authorized to request criminal history records. A "private security officer" is an individual whose primary duty is to perform security services for consideration, whether armed or unarmed. The term "security services" refers to acts that protect people or property as defined by regulations from the Attorney General. The term "State identification bureau" is the State entity designated by the Attorney General for the submission and receipt of criminal records. The State identification bureau is designated by the Attorney General for criminal history record information. SEC. 4. CRIMINAL HISTORY RECORD INFORMATION SEARCH. An authorized employer can submit fingerprints or other identification means of an employee for a criminal history record search. The employer must obtain written consent from the employee and provide confidential access to any information obtained. Upon request from an authorized employer, the Attorney General will conduct a criminal history record search through the FBI and provide the information to the requesting State identification bureau. Upon receipt of criminal history record information from the Attorney General, the State identification bureau can only use the information as specified. For participating States without qualification standards for private security officers, the State must inform authorized employers about an employee's felony convictions, offenses involving dishonesty or false statements within the past 10 years. An authorized employer can request a criminal history record search for an employee once every 12 months of continuous employment. If a participating State has qualification standards for private security officers, they must use the information received from the search to apply the State standards and notify the employer of the results. The Attorney General will issue regulations within 180 days of the Act's enactment, covering security measures, qualification standards for authorized employers, and fees for background checks. Falsely certifying as an authorized employer or misusing obtained information carries criminal penalties. The Director of the FBI may collect user fees for processing background checks under the Act, with additional fees to cover automation expenses. Violators misusing information obtained under the Act may face fines or imprisonment. The Act allows the Director of the FBI to collect user fees for background checks, with fines or imprisonment for violators. States can assess fees for administering the Act, and opt out by enacting a law or order.
